One of the key debates on Tuesday will be whether Monday’s spike in volatility (1) cleared the deck of volatile short-options positions, or (2) is likely to lead to further buying of volatility to cover the significant explicit and implicit short volatility
positions across investor types. We continue to believe that most volatility selling
strategies employed by institutional investors are structured with the potential for large VIX spikes in mind. While the one-day move in the VIX increase was unprecedented, a rapid spike in the VIX was not unforeseen.

The technical picture for markets started deteriorating on Friday with selloff
exacerbated by vol targeting strategies de-risking and market makers hedging options
positions. This was followed by short-term momentum turning negative midday
Monday with further selling pressure from trend following strategies. This weak technical backdrop occurred amidst one of the strongest
earnings seasons with very high percentage of companies surprising on top-line and EPS, and consensus sharply revising up estimates. With fundamental buyers largely absent in the market, the Dow suffered a 6% intraday decline on Monday. We see the market selloff entirely disconnected from fundamentals. While the sharp rise in volatility may contribute to further outflows from systematic strategies in the short-term, we believe fundamentals should ultimately prevail as companies continue to deliver double-digit earnings growth on US tax catalyst, global synchronized growth, and weaker USD. Also, we expect a ramp-up in shareholder return to provide support for equity prices. We estimate gross share repurchases alone could total $700-800 billion this year on the back of 18% consensus earnings growth (y/y), cash repatriation, and lower policy uncertainty. We reiterate our S&P 500 price target of 3,000. The current market valuation of 15x (based on consensus 2019 EPS of $171) is now inline with long-term average. We recommend investors buy the dip and start averaging in at current level. In particular, we still expect value, domestic, and small-cap tilts, which have significantly lagged the market (i.e., Russell 2000 has underperformed Large-caps by - 17% beta adjusted over the last twelve months), to outperform bond proxies.

BE11:21am

VIX options and VIX futures trading generated approximately 25% of CBOE's revenues in aggregate in 2H17 (roughly split between these two products) -- a meaningful growth driver for the company. We believe ETPs are an important part of the VIX ecosystem, but the growth and demand for CBOE's products has certainly been more broad based than from ETPs assets/issuers. However, we do note that when VIX has spiked in the past and the VIX futures term structure has flattened or become inverted (certain periods in 2015 and 2016), VIX futures open interest declined, along with volumes during a period of time thereafter. Our back-of-the-envelope math for XIV and SVXY suggests these two ETNs specifically could hold up to 25% of the short open interest in VIX futures specifically.

BE11:21am

This Sell-Off Begs the Question - We don't doubt that inflation fears and higher
rates gave investors pause and caused selling pressure at the end of last week and
today. However, the market sell-off today has been reported by news outlets (including
Bloomberg) as more technical and quant-driven. Did a crowded short-vol trade
exacerbate the sell-off? Short VIX/volatility is essentially a levered long market
position. A VIX spike past a certain level could have caused outflows and/or covering
on short vol trades, which then in turn causes more market selling and higher implied
volatility -- a "vicious cycle" to an extent. It's impossible to know how many assets were tied to short vol strategies precisely, so this is a wait-and-see until we get further details

Furthermore, we should not ignore high levels of capitalised interest nor the fact that it is burning cash. What a list eh, real stuff of a premium rating? We are in the process of re-initiating on Ocado but it looks like for FY2018 the Group has issued a profit warning to our minds. The Placing, also announced today, reflects the magnitude of cash burn for its NASA like projects; high in technological detail but one just never sees their benefit from Planet Earth. Oh to be such a charming company...

FY18 Group EBITDA to reflect Erith (CFC4) CapEx, ramp up of OSP in Andover n
(CFC3) and Erith and an acceleration in the development of OSP. Given the
multiple negative impacts highlighted to FY18, we believe the company isimplying material downgrades to consensus FY18 EBITDA (£104mn company
compiled, +£18mn YoY growth vs flat growth in FY17 on a comparable basis). Ocado
expects the trends in EBITDA to improve significantly in FY19.
FY18 Retail Revenue growth of 10%-15%: assuming economic conditions remain n
broadly stable. GSe 12.0% Retail sales growth for FY18.
FY18 Capex of c£210mn: for increased capacity (new CFCs, vans) and further n
investments in the Ocado Smart Platform. GSe FY18 Capex £149mn.
Aim to sign further international Solutions’ partners (not FY specific).

Mouselet Good morning miscellaneous and wealth-reduced capitalists

Given the multiple EBITDA headwinds highlighted for FY18, alongside flat EBITDA
growth delivered in FY17, we believe the company is implying material downgrades to
consensus FY18 EBITDA. GSe/company compiled EBITDA FY18 is £101mn/£104mn;
implying YoY growth of £15mn/£18mn vs flat growth in FY17.
While we believe raising capital and increasing short term P&L/capex investments are
the correct long term decisions for this business, particularly in the context of the
current market sell-off, we expect investors to react negatively to this release. Especially
given the share price has been very strong, with shares +32%/+87% in the last 1
month/3 months vs European food retail average of -1%+5% and vs European Internet
average of +16%+17%.

Petrofac has warned investors that the Serious Fraud Office is deepening its investigation into alleged bribery, corruption and money laundering at the troubled oil services company.

Shares in the FTSE 250 business fell by 4.3 per cent yesterday after it said that more of its directors were expected to be questioned by the fraud agency, some of them under caution, and that the inquiry was now "wide ranging in time and scope".

Ayman Asfari, chief executive of Petrofac, and Marwan Chedid, chief operating officer, were arrested and questioned under caution by the Serious Fraud Office last year.

BE11:54am

We largely analysed the Unaoil case and the potential impact in our initiation report “Refocus, reassure and restart”. The Unaoil story did not jeopardise the group’s balance sheet as banks did not recall the RCF; impact on commercial activities has been limited as Petrofac secured c. GBP5.2bn of contracts in 2017E (bang in line with our forecasts). We estimate that the maximum cash-out for penalty would be GBP1.05bn, however if a penalty is imposed, we think that the SFO would likely be flexible about the payment terms and timing, as clearly its objective is not to shut the company down. This investigation is also a brake on any M&A strategy. This maximum cash out is included in our valuation (300p negative impact on the SOP).

After a number of reputational incidents/risks, Petrofac needed to reassure investors. We think this has partly been done, thanks to: 1) good execution on projects; 2) industry recognition as a top downstream contractor in MEA; 3) net debt under control after action taken (cut in capex, dividend), together with a strong liquidity position; and 4) changes in its board structure and measures regarding the Unaoil investigation. We have a Buy rating and 600p TP, which is based on an SOP (8x EV/EBIT for E&C, 9x EV/EBIT for EPS, IES at book value).

BE12:03pm

What’s Going on? We think the central point of ShadowFall’s argument rests on
the JVs being vehicles for IQE to offload R&D, in essence, running cumulative
losses (through 2015-16) that would otherwise have been incurred by IQE in its
own accounts. Yet the accounting rules require IQE to write the JV down to a zero net
book value (NBV) on its balance sheet if cumulative losses exceed the initial investment
(which happened), thereby, not recognizing any of the excess losses incurred by the JV
beyond this point. While IQE’s accounting is therefore in line with the accounting rules,
ShadowFall still maintain that the JV is a ‘non-commercial’ entity (qualified in their mind
by IQE being the only customer across 2015-16) and somewhat of a ‘manipulator’ of the
accounting rules. But the counter argument is that IQE is not legally responsible
for the losses incurred in the JV and, therefore, it should not have to recognise
any further losses on its B/S. IQE also stated in its 2016 accounts that it expected
the JV to be loss-making for the initial 3 years of investment (such initial losses
obviously being common in many businesses) and that it could now have acquired
customers beyond IQE.

wayneJ And surely the term 'mysterious short seller' requires Matt Earl to have a black cat that he strokes whilst sitting on a swivel chair?

BE12:05pm

The investment case for IQE goes well beyond the supply of VCSEL wafers to Apple’s 3D
sensor chip suppliers. Other CS (compound semiconductor) applications include CREO
(cheaper silicon substrate), RF filters (3x the size of PA market), power switching (AC
to DC conversion, wireless chargers), base stations (4G to 5G migration), fibre optics
(DFBs & NIL (nano imprint lithography) grating), data centres (copper wire replacement),
infrared and solar. We argue that IQE could grow profits at close to 50% in 2019 based
almost entirely on VCSELs. Some of the other technologies are expected to contribute
before then and many more in 2020 and beyond, thus extending these superior growth
rates over the longer term and helping to justify a higher valuation multiple. We expect
the JVs to be an important part of the long term future for IQE although today we
conservatively ascribe zero value to them when arriving at our target price. The IQE story
is fundamentally about CS technologies that we expect to increasingly take the place of
silicon in certain global applications over the next five years and beyond.

Lefevre Since when do you enjoy reading about Joint Venture structures in accounts?
BE12:05pm

The principal criticisms centre on IQE's JVs and weak free cash flows.
Overall, we find the report very backward looking, it contains nothing that we were not
already aware of and does not appear to appreciate the extent of the opportunity for IQE
to become a global leader in multiple, very large, high growth, emergent industries.

BE12:06pm

We have previously commented that Wireless sales look set to fall from 70% to below
50% of the group over the next two years and high growth applications in Photonics
could generate over twice the margins currently enjoyed by Wireless. We have also noted
the reducing dependence on JV licence sales (zero in forecast for 2018) and how we
expect this to result in a higher quality earnings stream. We expect to introduce FY19
forecasts at the time of the final results on 20 March, when the company has said that
it will 'provide forward looking guidance'. Our preliminary look at 2019 suggests growth
of close to 50% compared with c.20% that we forecast for 2017 and 2018, years in
which growth at the Group level is being held back by the large, but relatively low growth
Wireless business. If correct, this would imply a 2019 P/E of under 20x.
